channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Magnetic fibres give this robot a soft grip
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03708-y

Researchers have come up with a way to weave fabric from fibres that can be controlled using magnetic fields.
item.dc:title: Magnetic fibres give this robot a soft grip
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Photoinduced twist and untwist of moiré superlattices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09707-3

Femtosecond photoexcitation drives a coherent twist–untwist motion of the moiré superlattice in 2° and 57° twisted WSe2/MoSe2 heterobilayers.
item.dc:title: Photoinduced twist and untwist of moiré superlattices

item.title: A universal speed limit for spreading of coherence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09735-z

Experiments reveal a speed limit for the spreading of spatial coherence during the formation of a weakly interacting Bose–Einstein condensate.
item.dc:title: A universal speed limit for spreading of coherence
item.dc:creator: Gevorg Martirosyan
Martin Gazo
Jiří Etrych
Simon M. Fischer
Sebastian J. Morris
Christopher J. Ho
Christoph Eigen
Zoran Hadzibabic

item.title: Silicon solar cells with hybrid back contacts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09681-w

Silicon solar cells with hybrid interdigitated back contacts have a power conversion efficiency approaching 95% of the theoretical limit and a fill factor approaching 98% of the theoretical limit.
item.dc:title: Silicon solar cells with hybrid back contacts
